US MARKET WRAP 27 April 2018: Markets close out the week with a whimper
content:
* SNAP-SHOT: Equities flat, Treasuries down, DXY flat, Crude down.
* REAR-VIEW: US GDP beat, UK GDP misses, North/South Korea prospect of denuclearization. 
* AHEAD: FOMC, Nonfarm Payrolls, Quarterly Refunding, Eurozone CPI, global PMIs, RBA. 

* GEOPOLITICS: North Korean leader Kim and South Korean President Moon completed their inter-Korean summit and released the “Panmunjom Declaration,” a document that pledges to work toward signing a peace deal this year ending the Korean War, denuclearizing the Korean Peninsula in phases, and developing inter-Korean relations leading toward reunification, Stratfor reported. “In practical terms, Kim and Moon agreed to a nonaggression pact, stated plans to resume family reunions on Aug. 15, set up an inter-Korean liaison office in Kaesong, halted propaganda activities on the Demilitarized Zone and began the process to connect cross-border railways and roads.” US President Trump welcomed progress between North and South Korea, and will meet with Kim in the coming weeks; US Vice President Pence commented that the US would meet any talks, promises or assurances from North Korea with reservation, vigilance, and verification. Trump also reiterated that Iran must not ‘get even close’ to nuclear weapons. The US House Intelligence Committee issued its Russia report, and the Republican report found no evidence of collusion between Trump campaign associates and Russia but affirms evidence that Russia interfered in the 2016 election. Elsewhere, at the margin, US President Trump seemed to intimate that he might intervene in the Russia investigation. 

* TRADE NEWS: NAFTA: Canada’s foreign minister again reiterated that progress was being made on NAFTA talks, particularly in the area of auto content. After Mexico’s economy minister Guajardo and Freeland stayed in Washington yesterday and today to thrash out a deal, expectations are high a deal will be reached (Mexcio says an agreement is close, Canada is more cautious) – earlier in the week, sources reported that a deal could be reached as soon as 1/May, though on Friday, other sources said ministers were due to meet again on 7 May; the news is in line with earlier timelines suggested by both Mexican and Canadian policymakers. TRUMP/MERKEL: During his press conference with German Chancellor Merkel, President Trump wants to "remedy" trade imbalances with the EU. German Chancellor Merkel said Germany will continue to be a reliable trade partner to the US, Germany is committed to free trade within the WTO framework, but she noted that there are some shortcomings, in an apparent nod to some of Trump’s arguments. On trade between the US/EU, Merkel avoided answering a question on whether EU and Germany will be exempt from US steel/aluminium tariffs, says Trump will make a decision.

* DATA: US Q1 GDP data surprised to the upside, slowing from 2.9% in Q4, but at 2.3%, beat expectations of 2.0%; the internals show that consumer spending and business investment slowed, though the PCE measures point to inflation rising. The data is unlikely to concern the Fed, particularly given that Q1 has often seen a ‘weather impact’ in recent years. Analysts were focussing, however, on the slowdown in consumption (1.1% vs 4.0% in Q4), but Capital Economics says that was partly due to the drop back in motor vehicles spending, following a post-hurricane spike at the end of last year. University of Michigan final April data was encouraging, with sentiment printing 98.8 against an expected 98.0, conditions a touch below expectations at 114.9, while expectations were revised up. The inflation gauges were unchanged for the year-ahead, though the 5 to 10-year gauge rose 0.1ppts to 2.5%. 

* EQUITIES: SPX +0.15% at 2670, NDX +0.10% at 6656, DJI -0.05 at 24310. Energy -1.2%, Materials -0.2%, Industrials -0.1%, Consumer discretionary +0.5%, Consumer staples +0.6%, Healthcare +0.5%, Financials +0.1%, IT -0.3%, Telecoms +1.8%, Utilities +1.0%. Equity futures are negative for the week, but closed out the week on a whimper, with most of the action horizontal – there was some negative ticks in afternoon trade, though the ES was content to consolidate beneath the 2670.  M&A: Reports suggest that Sprint (S) is seeking to finalise its merger with T-Mobile (TMUS) which could come as soon as next week. Praxair (PX) and Linde AG received CFIUS clearance for their business combination, and the deal is seen completing in the second half of the year. ENERGY: Was the biggest laggard, with some of the big names reporting; Exxon (XOM) beat on revenues but miss on EPS, suggesting that higher crude prices aren’t solving the issues, Chevron (CVX) beat on EPS though missed on revs. There wasn’t much support from crude prices. TECH: FAANGs were mixed; Amazon (AMZN) was higher after a solid earnings report, though the rest of the group were struggling to carve out gains, and tech shares were generally soft, as was INTC despite solid earnings. Elsewhere in tech, ahead of its earnings, reports suggest that Apple (AAPL) will manufacture 8 million iPhone X units in Q2 as it looks to drive down its inventory. CONS DISC: Charter Communications (CHTR) was slammed after reporting the loss of more internet and TV subscribers than expected, with Comcast (CMCSA) and Altice (ATC) falling in sympathy. 

* TREASURIES: The Treasury curve bull-flattened on Friday, with short-dated yields narrowing by around 1bps, while the longer-end of the curve saw yields drop by around 5bps at settlement. The buying resulted in further narrowing of major curve spreads – on the week, 2s30s narrows by around 3bps, 5s30s narrowed by around 2bps, while 2s10s flattened by around 2bps in the week. There was some selling action after better than expected US GDP on Friday, though the selling was reversed shortly afterwards, as the sell-off in tech shares prompted buying in the long-end of the curve. 

* CRUDE: WTI (June) futures settle 9 cents lower at 68.10/bbl; Brent (June) settled 10 cents lower at 67.98/bbl. Despite both slipping on the day, Brent is on track for its third week of gains, though WTI finishes red. Dollar strength was touted as a contributing factor to the daily weakness, being helped along after a soft UK GDP report, while talk of profit-taking after a decent run was also cited, as well as the slight easing in global geopolitical tensions after the meeting between North and South Korea. During the press conference between US President Trump and German Chancellor Merkel, crude came under pressure, likely as a result of positive comments made by Trump regarding geopolitics regarding North Korea, though Trump was more vague (and stern) with regards to Iran. Just a few months ago, analysts were struggling to place a bullish narrative around the crude complex, however, the upside bias is being seen in many analyst notes as of late: A note from BofAML’s analysts was receiving attention, with the bank said to see Brent prices above $80 in Q1. Meanwhile, analysts at PVM are looking for crude to consolidate around current levels (though will be subject to bouts of profit-taking) ahead of 12/May, when the US will decide whether to pull-out of the Iran nuclear deal (bullish crude, is the theory), or stay in/amend the current deal (bearish crude, the theory goes). Baker Hughes reported oil drillers added rigs for the fourth straight week, with the weekly count rising by 5 to 825 (total up 8 to 1021), though there was little impact on crude prices. Analysts continue to monitor the situation in Venezuela; sources reported that the country will have to make full debt payments to China following the lapse of a grace period, and will have to ship 375k BPD to meet those obligations. Elsewhere, Philips 66 again called for more pipeline capacity in the Permian Basin, amid mounting evidence that US pipelines are struggling to handle the boost in US production, and the pipeline situation is reported to be weighing on local prices. 

* FOREX: DXY The broad Dollar has eased off best levels in wake of some mixed US data beneath a headline Q1 GDP beat, but remains on track to continue its recent renaissance, with the index almost extending gains to resistance just ahead of 92.000 having started the week around 90.300. In terms of drivers along with the charts turning more positive as upside levels were surpassed, less angst on the trade and geopolitical front, plus some upbeat economic indicators and last, but by no means least weakness in rival currencies. GBP Friday’s biggest G10 loser and underperformer by some distance, and largely due to a much bleaker than expected 1st look at Q1 UK growth, which was only modestly impacted by bad weather to add insult to injury. This put a further big dent in May BoE rate hike prospects with some market measures assigning less than a 20% chance vs 50% before the release. Cable extended last week’s already heavy losses from 1.3900+ to circa 1.3750, with little in the way of support seen until just ahead of the next downside big figure. Even Eur/Gbp rebounded through 0.8700 and just over 0.8750 amidst ongoing weakness in the single currency. Sterling appears on track to end April as the fall guy having been among the most attractive on seasonal and other factors with just one day to go. EUR/JPY/CHF All undermined by dovish/downbeat Central Bank policy pronouncements after the ECB acknowledged a slowdown in growth and did not even discuss life after the current end of QE in September, while the BoJ removed its timetable for inflation reaching target and the SNB maintained that the Franc is still highly valued, albeit not has strong as it has been. Eur/Usd tumbled further from brief post-ECB meeting peaks around 1.2210 to a 1.2055 low and testing support down to 1.2550, but bounced in the run up to another big option expiry cluster at the NY cut (3 bn at the 1.2100 strike after 5+ bn at 1.2200 ran off on Thursday). Usd/Jpy spiked just above 109.50 at one stage, but faded ahead of a 109.65 Fib again to revisit the 109.00 handle. Usd/Chf reached 0.9900 before easing back amidst broad Greenback consolidation and profit taking. AUD/NZD/CAD The non-US Dollars all held up better during the final trading session of the week, but after hefty declines since the previous Friday on a mixture of disappointing data, cross flows, technicals and CB vibes suggesting no hurry to raise rates whatsoever. Aud/Usd slipped further towards the next downside round number at 0.7500, Nzd/Usd tested sub-0.7050 as the cross climbed back over 1.0700 and Usd/Cad rallied to 1.2900 before easing back. Note, the Kiwi could have drawn some traction from one end of the month bank model suggesting Nzd/Usd upside. SEK The Krona was undermined by the Riksbank pushing back rate hike projections until late 2018 in response to weaker than forecast Swedish inflation developments, with Eur/Sek up to 8 year highs over 10.5400, but then fading alongside the Eur in general to sub-10.5000. Note, Ohlsson dissented in favour of a hike to -0.25% from 0.50%, but this was largely shrugged off and a lone, outlying hawkish shout. TRY/MXN The Lira got a belated lift after the CBRT jacked up its LLW by a bigger than expected 75 basis points to 13.50% with Usd/Try retesting lows just above 4.0000, while the Peso was supported by more reports suggesting that a NAFTA accord may be reached early next month – Usd/Mxn sub-18.7000.

* WEEK AHEAD: Next week’s docket is packed with tier one releases; from the US, FOMC (Weds), Treasury Quarterly Refunding (Weds) and Payrolls (Friday) stand out, while ISM surveys will also garner attention; Canada and Mexico watchers will focus on NAFTA talks, with a deal expected to be reached next week; In APAC, RBA reports on Tuesday ahead of its SOMP on Friday, and a host of PMI data will be released globally. Read RANsquawk’s full preview here.

content:
DXY

The broad Dollar has eased off best levels in wake of some mixed US data beneath a headline Q1 GDP beat, but remains on track to continue its recent renaissance, with the index almost extending gains to resistance just ahead of 92.000 having started the week around 90.300. In terms of drivers along with the charts turning more positive as upside levels were surpassed, less angst on the trade and geopolitical front, plus some upbeat economic indicators and last, but by no means least weakness in rival currencies.

GBP  

Friday’s biggest G10 loser and underperformer by some distance, and largely due to a much bleaker than expected 1st look at Q1 UK growth, which was only modestly impacted by bad weather to add insult to injury. This put a further big dent in May BoE rate hike prospects with some market measures assigning less than a 20% chance vs 50% before the release. Cable extended last week’s already heavy losses from 1.3900+ to circa 1.3750, with little in the way of support seen until just ahead of the next downside big figure. Even Eur/Gbp rebounded through 0.8700 and just over 0.8750 amidst ongoing weakness in the single currency. Sterling appears on track to end April as the fall guy having been among the most attractive on seasonal and other factors with just one day to go.

EUR/JPY/CHF

All undermined by dovish/downbeat Central Bank policy pronouncements after the ECB acknowledged a slowdown in growth and did not even discuss life after the current end of QE in September, while the BoJ removed its timetable for inflation reaching target and the SNB maintained that the Franc is still highly valued, albeit not has strong as it has been. Eur/Usd tumbled further from brief post-ECB meeting peaks around 1.2210 to a 1.2055 low and testing support down to 1.2550, but bounced in the run up to another big option expiry cluster at the NY cut (3 bn at the 1.2100 strike after 5+ bn at 1.2200 ran off on Thursday). Usd/Jpy spiked just above 109.50 at one stage, but faded ahead of a 109.65 Fib again to revisit the 109.00 handle. Usd/Chf reached 0.9900 before easing back amidst broad Greenback consolidation and profit taking.

AUD/NZD/CAD   

The non-US Dollars all held up better during the final trading session of the week, but after hefty declines since the previous Friday on a mixture of disappointing data, cross flows, technicals and CB vibes suggesting no hurry to raise rates whatsoever. Aud/Usd slipped further towards the next downside round number at 0.7500, Nzd/Usd tested sub-0.7050 as the cross climbed back over 1.0700 and Usd/Cad rallied to 1.2900 before easing back. Note, the Kiwi could have drawn some traction from one end of the month bank model suggesting Nzd/Usd upside.

SEK

The Krona was undermined by the Riksbank pushing back rate hike projections until late 2018 in response to weaker than forecast Swedish inflation developments, with Eur/Sek up to 8 year highs over 10.5400, but then fading alongside the Eur in general to sub-10.5000. Note, Ohlsson dissented in favour of a hike to -0.25% from 0.50%, but this was largely shrugged off and a lone, outlying hawkish shout.

TRY/MXN

The Lira got a belated lift after the CBRT jacked up its LLW by a bigger than expected 75 basis points to 13.50% with Usd/Try retesting lows just above 4.0000, while the Peso was supported by more reports suggesting that a NAFTA accord may be reached early next month – Usd/Mxn sub-18.7000.

subject: Barclays FX Month-End Rebalancing model sees weak USD selling
content:
NOTE: Scale is '+++' through neutral to '---' 

Barclays says "geopolitical tensions helped push oil prices higher, which got reflected in raising US breakevens and higher Treasury yields. The USD was supported by higher rates, outperforming its major peers, while bond markets were under pressure. Equities did not suffer from higher interest rates and were modestly up across major economies, but US equities printed lower percentage returns in local currency than other majors. The strong dollar added to the fall in bond markets values (in dollar terms) out of the US, which was more pronounced in Europe and Japan. As such, the model produces neutral-to-weak dollar selling signals."

subject: DEBT LATEST: bonds pare more losses after early US data
content: Somewhat mixed and delayed via some providers, but ultimately the 1st take of US Q1 GDP beat consensus on the headline y/y growth measure and fixed income has fixated or at least focused on that. Hence, US Treasuries are off best levels, albeit still bull-flattening, while Bunds and Gilts sit at 158.64 and 121.84 respectively (still 33 and 47 ticks ahead, but 14 and 18 ticks down from their post-poor UK GDP data Eurex and Liffe intraday peaks). Next up, Michigan sentiment and BoE speeches, while along with the normal pre-weekend positioning debt markets may see some extra price action related to month end on Monday.

Capital Economics says tougher times lie ahead for the US stock markets; sees S&P 500 end-2018 at 2600, end-2019 at 2300, end-2020 at 2500
content:
• S&P 500 slipping from record highs mainly due to worries about protectionism, regulation and geopolitics. But even if these fears recede, CapEco sees the index falling.
  • It says the key reason is the changing outlook for monetary policy, which has been very loose since the bull market began in 2009. "Admittedly, the Fed began to raise its policy rate over two years ago and is now also shrinking its balance sheet. But its policy rate is still very low, while its asset holdings are only being cut very gradually. And unconventional monetary policy in the developed world overall has become more accommodative."
  • CapEco says that very loose monetary policy has boosted equity prices for two reasons: 1) facilitated a recovery in economic activity and corporate profits, 2) it cut investors’ required return from risky assets. "Accordingly, 70% of the gain in the S&P 500 during the bull market has been due to higher earnings, and 30% to a higher price/earnings ratio," adding that "Clearly, monetary policy is not the only factor to have affected these two variables. Corporate tax cuts, for example, have driven up earnings recently. Yet it is likely to have been a key one." 
  • "In the past, tighter Fed policy has eventually taken a toll on the US economy, with the S&P 500 usually turning a bit sooner," CapEco says, and it expects this to happen again, even if continued very loose monetary policy in the rest of the world prolongs the bull market. "Admittedly," the consultancy writes, "we are not forecasting a recession in the US, which has nearly always been bad news for the S&P 500. But we do expect the economy there to slow significantly."

UBS no longer sees BOE raising rates in May, and now sees no prospect of UK hikes in 2018E
content:
• In the wake of cautious comments from Gov Carney, a very weak Q1 GDP print has ended the chances of a rate hike in May. For us, it means no hike at all in 2018 
  • Q1 GDP grows just +0.1%, much weaker than the +0.3% expected by the MPC: The first estimate of UK Q1 GDP of +0.1% q/q / +1.2% y/y has for us ended any real prospect of a 25bp increase in Bank Rate being sanctioned when the MPC announces its next decision on 10th May.We revert to our prior forecast of Bank Rate remaining on hold at 0.50% over the forecast horizon. Following on the heels of several disappointing empirical and sentiment data releases over recent weeks, both in the UK and elsewhere, a print this weak would have severely dented expectations of a hike even had the Governor not already acknowledged growing doubts a week ago.
  • A lot has changed in a month, none of it for the better: The minutes of the previous MPC meeting, published on the 22nd March, explicitly referred to "the market-implied probability of a 25bp increase at the May meeting (of) around 90%", and in our opinion contained very little to push back against that level of conviction. The minutes did note the cut in the Bank of England staff's expectation for Q1 GDP from 0.4% to 0.3% q/q, but attributed that to the impact of the bad weather last month, and stuck to the view that underlying GDP would grow by around 0.4% in the quarter. Revision-prone as first estimates of UK GDP notoriously are, we believe it would be untenable to repeat that assertion in May given the extent of this downside miss.
  • Implied probability following Carney's comments and GDP print below 25%: The apparently deliberate warning from the Governor in comments during a BBC interview last week that a May hike was less clear cut than the market was implying have amplified the reaction to this very soft GDP estimate. It seems inconceivable to us now that Mr Carney will vote for a hike at the next meeting, and while other members may hold different views, it is hard to imagine any but the most hawkish deeming a hike in May to be appropriate. We now expect a 7-2 split vote as in March, with external members Ian McCafferty and Michael Saunders likely prepared to assume the pronounced recent data weakness is transitory and exaggerated by inclement weather, and to advocate immediately pushing ahead with tighter policy.
  • The MPC will for now deem recent weakness as temporary and stick to its guns: The overall message from the MPC on 10th May - in the minutes of their meeting, and the accompanying QIR and press conference - is likely to remain upbeat and positive. The economy will be predicted to bounce back in Q2 from temporary (albeit more pronounced than expected) weakness in the first quarter, and forecasts of accelerating earnings and ongoing underlying growth of around 0.4% q/q will not be revised, in our view. They are likely to repeat their prediction that rates are expected to rise gradually over the course of this year and beyond.
  • We view the slowdown as more serious, and see no prospect of hikes in 2018E: While the extent of the loss of momentum in Q1 may indeed have been exaggerated by the bad weather, we think there are deeper fundamental drivers of slowing activity that are set to persist. Brexit-related anxiety is a headwind that is blowing more strongly as time goes by without the full guarantee of a transitional deal, and with very little clarity on future arrangements post-exit. The slow motion slowdown we have warned of many times is continuing to materialise, and with inflation likely to return to target within the next 3-6 months, we believe the case for higher rates will look increasingly threadbare from both real activity and inflation standpoints.

content:

  • Soft UK growth data leads to a weaker GBP and lifts FTSE
  • BoJ keeps monetary policy unchanged Kuroda reiterates it is appropriate to continue powerful monetary easing

ASIA

Asia equity markets traded mostly higher as the region got an uplift from the momentum in US where all majors extended on gains amid tech outperformance after strong Facebook results, which was later followed after-market by Amazon, Intel, Microsoft and Western Digital which all beat on earnings forecasts. As such, ASX 200 (+0.2%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.5%) traded positive although gains were relatively mild as participants also digested a flurry of data releases and earnings, while KOSPI (+0.6%) benefited from a warming of ties amid the historic inter-Korean summit. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-0.7%) and Hang Seng (+0.2%) were mixed with underperformance in the mainland following a neutral position by the PBoC in today’s open market operations, while data also showed a slowdown in the pace of Chinese Industrial Profit growth. Finally, 10yr JGBs were marginally higher with prices underpinned at the open to track the upside in USTs and with gains then held throughout the session including after an uneventful BoJ announcement in which it kept policy unchanged but removed the wording on reaching inflation goal around FY19.

CENTRAL BANKS

BoJ kept monetary policy unchanged as expected with NIRP held at -0.10% and the 10yr JGB yield target at around 0%.

The decision was made by 8-1 vote with Kataoka the dissenter again, while the central bank removed its reference to achieving 2% CPI target around FY19. Furthermore, BoJ stated that risks to economy were balanced for FY2018 but are skewed to downside for FY2019. (Newswires)

BoJ Governor Kuroda says it is appropriate to continue powerful monetary easing, says that the timeframe for a price target was a limit implying immediate policy change, adds was just a forecast, not a limit and inflation momentum to continue faster to the 2% target. (Newswires)

ECB’s Survey of Professional Forecasters maintains 2018 inflation at 1.5%, cuts 2019 inflation to 1.6% to 1.7%. (Newswires)

 

ECB's Mersch (Hawkish) says path of normalization remains conditional on outlook for price stability, adds underlying strength of Euro area economy continues to support their confidence that inflation will converge to their aim. (Newswires)

 

SNB’s Jordan says there has been a reduction in significant overvaluation of CHF however the currency remains overvalued; he adds negative interest rates and market intervention remain essential as situation is still fragile. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

Stocks pushed higher (Stoxx 600 +0.1%) post Thursday earnings as tech outperformance buoyed general sentiment, alongside an easing of geopolitical tensions following constructive dialog between Korea’s leaders. FTSE saw significant strengthening following uninspiring GDP data, that weakened the GBP and further reduced the possibility of tighter monetary policy. While expectations were focused on bad weather having a significant adverse impact, this was quoted to have had only a “limited effect” which pushed expectations of a rate hike in May to sub 25% from 50-50 prior.

Positive earnings seen from Klepierre (+0.5%), Daimler (+0.5%) and Saint Gobain (+3.2%) and negative from Sanofi (-1.7%) and Renault (-3.7%). Shire shares +1.0% after a top ten shareholder is said to be holding out for a higher offer or more cash in Takeda's (4502 JT) takeover.

FX

DXY

The index is gathering momentum, largely at the expense of the Greenback’s currency counterparts in the basket (and beyond), and has now cleared a few more chart resistance levels, around 91.526 and from 90.702-751, with the latter entering a multi-month channel that targets 91.996 ahead of 92.000 for more obvious psychological rather than technical reasons. DXY high so far is around 91.825, and another supportive factor comes from month-end rebalancing models signalling net Dollar demand.

GBP

Sterling’s dramatic turnaround from flavour of the month to one of the market’s worst enemies continues after the UK economy came to a virtual standstill in Q1 and not all because of the Beast from East, according to the ONS. BoE tightening expectations have been knocked back accordingly, with a May hike now down to circa 20% from evens pre-data and almost baked in at one stage (before misses on the labour, CPI and retail sales fronts last week). Cable is now threatening to lose the 1.3800 handle vs just over 1.4000 at the start of April/Q2 and the 1.4375 post-Brexit vote peak set only recently (on April 17).

EUR/JPY/CHF

All reeling and feeling the weight of dovish/downbeat Central Bank policy pronouncements after the ECB acknowledged a slowdown in growth, the BoJ removed its timetable for inflation reaching target and the SNB maintained that the Franc is still highly valued, albeit not has strong as it has been. Eur/Usd has tumbled further from brief post-meeting peaks around 1.2210 to a low of circa 1.2065 and eyeing a 1.2050 Fib for potential support, while Usd/Jpy is consolidating gains above 109.00, but remains capped just ahead of 109.50 and the 109.65 Fib. Usd/Chf has breached 0.9900, but Eur/Chf is sub-1.2000 on the aforementioned single currency weakness.

AUD/NZD/CAD  

Somewhat side-lined in the G10 arena and narrowly mixed vs their US peer, but with Aud/Usd slipping further towards the next downside round number at 0.7500, Nzd/Usd testing sub-0.7050 as the cross climbs back over 1.0700 and Usd/Cad up to 1.2900 before easing back. Note however, the Kiwi may get some respite/traction from one end of month model suggesting Nzd/Usd upside.

FIXED INCOME

Gilts are staging another attempt to clear technical and big figure resistance at 122.00 after the initial post-GDP rally petered out at 122.07, and with a 2nd wind the 10 year debt future made it to 122.12 (+3/4 point exactly). Perhaps the corresponding cash yield is finding 1.45% sticky, but Short Sterling futures have extended pre-data gains to as much as 8 ticks as May BoE rate hike odds continue to rise from evens to around 3:1 or even 4-5:1 depending on where you look. Elsewhere, Bunds are tagging along with a lag and have climbed to 158.78 (+47 ticks), while BTPs are unwinding more of their recent outperformance as political jitters resurface and a degree of Italian supply concession is factored in. US Treasuries remain firm nearer overnight peaks than troughs and with the curve re-flattening ahead of advance US Q1 GDP and more top-tier data.

COMMODITIES

As we approach week end some profit taking noted in the crude complex, that has been further compounded by FX effects, with not much specific news aside from a fire in a Wisconsin oil refinery that had little effect on the fossil fuel. In the metals scope reports were seen from the EU that conditions being set by the US to extend tariff deadlines were unacceptable, with a slight rise in aluminium seen. Gold currently at almost 5 week lows, with the yellow metal heading for its biggest weekly fall in a month. 

  • Looking ahead, highlights include, US GDP, ECB’s Lautenschlaeger and BoE’s Carney

subject: EU MID SESSION UPDATE  Weak UK GDP weakens the GBP
content:
COMMODITIES

As we approach week end some profit taking noted in the crude complex, that has been further compounded by FX effects, with not much specific news aside from a fire in a Wisconsin oil refinery that had little effect on the fossil fuel. In the metals scope reports were seen from the EU that conditions being set by the US to extend tariff deadlines were unacceptable, with a slight rise in aluminium seen. Gold currently at almost 5 week lows, with the yellow metal heading for its biggest weekly fall in a month.  

EQUITIES

Stocks pushed higher (Stoxx 600 +0.2%) post Thursday earnings as tech outperformance buoyed general sentiment, alongside an easing of geopolitical tensions following constructive dialog between Korea’s leaders. FTSE saw significant strengthening following uninspiring GDP data, that weakened the GBP and further reduced the possibility of tighter monetary policy. While expectations were focused on bad weather having a significant adverse impact, this was quoted to have had only a “limited effect” which pushed expectations of a rate hike in May to sub 25% from 50-50 prior.

Positive earnings seen from Klepierre (+0.5%), Daimler (+0.6%) and Saint Gobain (+2.6%) and negative from Sanofi (-2.0%) and Renault (-4.0%). Shire shares +1.0% after a top ten shareholder is said to be holding out for a higher offer or more cash in Takeda's (4502 JT) takeover.

Bunds: building on modest initial gains
content: A rather tepid opening mark-up for the 10 year German benchmark given the scale of recovery gains in US Treasuries, and perhaps this reflects the extent of the post-ECB rally seen by the end of President Draghi’s press conference and Q&A yesterday. However, Bunds are grinding higher after an initial mark-up to 158.38 from Thursday’s 158.31 Eurex close, reaching 158.61 before losing some momentum ahead of the EU cash bourse opens and a raft of data still to come on the penultimate session ahead of month end. Moreover, Friday’s scheduled ECB speakers are from the hawkish-leaning faction and could put their case forward amidst some reports that Draghi declined a request from Nowotny to put policy guidance beyond the current end of QE in September on the agenda. Back to the futures, and tech-wise 158.74-80 is seen as the nearest resistance area before the 21 DMA at 158.92, while chart support maybe too far away to mention, but for the record 157.90 is flagged by some technicians.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
27th April 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asia equity markets traded mostly higher as the region got an uplift from the momentum in US where all majors extended on gains amid tech outperformance after strong Facebook results, which was later followed after-market by Amazon, Intel, Microsoft and Western Digital which all beat on earnings forecasts. As such, ASX 200 (+0.2%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.5%) traded positive although gains were relatively mild as participants also digested a flurry of data releases and earnings, while KOSPI (+0.6%) benefited from a warming of ties amid the historic inter-Korean summit. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-0.7%) and Hang Seng (+0.2%) were mixed with underperformance in the mainland following a neutral position by the PBoC in today’s open market operations, while data also showed a slowdown in the pace of Chinese Industrial Profit growth. Finally, 10yr JGBs were marginally higher with prices underpinned at the open to track the upside in USTs and with gains then held throughout the session including after an uneventful BoJ announcement in which it kept policy unchanged but removed the wording on reaching inflation goal around FY19.

FTSE

Shire (SHP LN) - a top ten shareholder in Shire is holding out for a higher offer or more cash in Takeda's (4502 JT) takeover. (Times)

Shell (RDSA LN) - The co. has said it would write down the assets held in its Groningen field, following the Dutch decision to phase out gas production by 2030. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

DAX

Bayer (BAYN GY)/ BASF (BAS GY) – Bayer signs an agreement to sell further crop science businesses to BASF for up to EUR 1.7bln. Bayer businesses generated total sales of EUR 745mln in 2017. Sales is subject to successful closing of Monsanto (MON) acquisition. (Newswires)

Deutsche Telekom (DTK GY) - Softbank is seen to be making progress on a merger with T Mobile; AT&T and Verizon have also reportedly expressed interest. (Newswires)

Daimler (DAI GY) - The co. reports Q1 revenues of EUR 39.8bln vs. Exp. EUR 40.1bln, and net profit of EUR 2.35bln vs. Exp. EUR 2.29bln. (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

CAC

Klepierre (LI FP) – Q1 revenue EUR 331.5mln vs. Prev. EUR 320.6mln. Q1 total gross rental income EUR 310mln vs. Prev. EUR 300.4mln. Co. confirms  2018 outlook. The co. has said it is still interested in purchasing British assets following its failed Hammerson takeover. (Newswires)

Saint Gobain (SGO FP) – Q1 sales down 1.8% from last year to EUR 9.755bln. Sales +1.6% on a comparable basis. Co. reaffirms 2018 target for further LFL increase in operating income. Q1 sales impacted by US dollar weakness and other currency swings, as well as unfavourable weather conditions. (Newswires)

Airbus (AIR FP) - The co. and United Technologies (UTX) are planning to join force in component and service costs in order to lower the Bombardier CSeries cost, so as to make it easier to market. Aside from this, The co. reported revenues of EUR10bln vs. Exp. EUR 9.8bln and an adj. EBIT of EUR 14mln vs. Exp. EUR -15.7mln, confirms their 2018 guidance. (Newswires)

Capgemini (CAP FP) - Reported Q1 revenues of EUR 3.153bln up 7.2% on prev., growth accelerates in 2018. The co. confirms their FY targets for revenue growth, operating margin and free cash flow. (Newswires)

Kering (KER FP) -The luxury groups' CEO said they are continuing their collaboration with tax authorities over investigation into its Gucci brand, adding that the co. is not aware of the sums under scrutiny. (Newswires)

Sanofi (SAN FP) - The co. reports Q1 sales at EUR 7.898bln vs Exp 8.008bln, and net income of EUR 1.598bln vs. Exp. EUR 1.419bln, confirms 2018 outlook. (Newswires)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

Rexel (RXL FP) - The co. reported a Q1 recurring net income of EUR 68.2mln up 0.1% YY, adj. EBITDA of EUR 127mln down 4.8% YY, and sales of EUR 3.18bln up 3.9% YY. (Newswires)

SEB (SK FP) – Q1 sales +2.1% at EUR  1.56bln. Q1 negative currency effect on sales of 5.6%. Group aims to achieve an organic FY sales growth exceeding 5% (Newswires)

Icade (ICAD FP) - The co. reports Q1 revenue of EUR 362.1mln up 8.4%, and net current cash flow has been confirmed up 5% YY. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

SMI

OTHER SWISS COMPANIES

PAN EUROPE

BBVA ( BBVA SM) – Q1 net profit EUR 1.34bln vs. Exp. EUR 1.16bln. Revenue EUR 6.1bln vs. Prev. EUR 6.38bln. Fully loaded CET1 capital ratio 10.9% at end of March. Return on tangible equity 14.6% at end of March. (Newswires)

Caixabank (CABK SM) - The co. reports net profit of EUR 704mln vs. Exp. 573.7mln, net interest income of EUR 1.20bln vs. prev. EUR 1.20bln, CET1 ratio fully loaded of 11.6% at end-March. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

SCANDINAVIA

Volvo (VOLVB SS) – Q1 operating profit +3.6% at SEK 3.62bln. Revenue +19% at SEK 56.8bln. Co. expects continued strong growth in revenue and sales to remain strong.

ICA Gruppen (ICA SS) – The co. reports Q1 net sales of SEK 27.18bln vs. Exp. SEK 26.8bln and operating profit of SEK 972mln vs. prev. SEK 996mln.

BROKER MOVES

US

EQUITIES: SPX +1.04% at 2667, NDX +2.08% at6650 , DJI +0.99% at 24322

SECTORS: Cons Cyclicals:  +1.44%, Cons Non-Cyclicals: +0.73%, Energy: +1.33%, Financials: +0.31%, Health Care: +1.28%, Industrials: -0.27%, Materials: +0.59%, Technology: +2.44%, Telecoms: -3.12%, Utilities: +1.00%. 

Equity futures carried on from yesterday’s rebound and traded higher throughout most of Thursday’s session with no real catalyst pushing stocks (though some observers noted that yields on 10-year Treasuries were under 3.00%). The S&P 500 Emini was contained within the 2640-2670 range and only in later trade broke through the 2670, before falling back below that level. Technology was the leading sector today following decent earnings from Facebook (FB), which helped FAANG stocks, but some weakness was seen in Apple (AAPL) after another research note raising concerns about iPhone demand which caught further attention (Bernstein).

Amazon.com Inc (AMZN) - Q1 EPS USD 1.48 vs. Exp. USD 1.28, revenue USD 51.0bln vs. Exp. USD 49.77bln. (Newswires)

Microsoft Corp (MSFT) - Q1 EPS USD 0.95 vs. Exp. USD 0.85, revenue USD 27.0bln vs. Exp. USD 25.77bln. (Newswires)

Intel Corp (INTC) - Q1 EPS USD 0.87 vs. Exp. USD 0.72, revenue USD 16.1bln vs. Exp. USD 15.08bln; boosts guidance. (Newswires)

  • Asian equity markets mostly higher amid outperformance in tech names and after the inter-Korean summit
  • USD remained firm as EUR/USD hovers around 1.2100
  • Looking ahead, highlights include UK & US GDP, ECB’s Mersch & Lautenschlaeger and BoE’s Carney

 

ASIA

Asia equity markets traded mostly higher as the region got an uplift from the momentum in US where all majors extended on gains amid tech outperformance after strong Facebook results, which was later followed after-market by Amazon, Intel, Microsoft and Western Digital which all beat on earnings forecasts. As such, ASX 200 (+0.2%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.5%) traded positive although gains were relatively mild as participants also digested a flurry of data releases and earnings, while KOSPI (+0.6%) benefited from a warming of ties amid the historic inter-Korean summit. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-0.7%) and Hang Seng (+0.2%) were mixed with underperformance in the mainland following a neutral position by the PBoC in today’s open market operations, while data also showed a slowdown in the pace of Chinese Industrial Profit growth. Finally, 10yr JGBs were marginally higher with prices underpinned at the open to track the upside in USTs and with gains then held throughout the session including after an uneventful BoJ announcement in which it kept policy unchanged but removed the wording on reaching inflation goal around FY19.

BoJ kept monetary policy unchanged as expected with NIRP held at -0.10% and the 10yr JGB yield target at around 0%.
The decision was made by 8-1 vote with Kataoka the dissenter again, while the central bank removed its reference to achieving 2% CPI target around FY19. Furthermore, BoJ stated that risks to economy were balanced for FY2018 but are skewed to downside for FY2019. (Newswires)

Chinese Industrial Profits (Mar) Y/Y 3.1% (Prev. 10.8%). (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK GfK Consumer Confidence (Apr) -9 vs. Exp. -7 (Prev. -7). (Newswires)

UK Parliament voted in favour to urge the government to pursue customs union, as expected. (Newswires)

EU Chief Brexit Negotiator Barnier repeated that the UK transition is not certain until a Brexit deal is reached, adding that market participants should prepare for a 'no transition' outcome. (Newswires)

ECB sources stated that policymakers are keen not to upset market expectations regarding an end of QE this year and a rate hike in mid-2019, while sources suggested a decision is seen in June or July with chance of a delay to September. (Newswires)
 

FX

In FX markets, the DXY remained firm and held near the prior day’s best levels as its major counterparts EUR and GBP consolidated from yesterday’s swings with EUR/USD stuck near the 1.2100 level. USD/JPY and JPY-crosses were also lacklustre amid mixed releases including softer than expected Tokyo CPI and Retail Sales data, although Industrial Production was more encouraging and topped estimates, while an unchanged BoJ policy announcement also ensured price action was uneventful. Elsewhere, KRW strengthened overnight amid the inter-Korean summit in which North Korea Leader Kim became his nation’s first leader to step on South Korea territory since 1953.

NAFTA countries are aiming for a May 1st agreement although big issues remain, according to sources familiar with the matter. However, Mexico’s Foreign Minister Videgaray stated they are reasonably near to a NAFTA deal and that an agreement is definitely possible in a few days. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

Commodities saw lacklustre trade during Asia hours in which WTI crude futures slightly retreated below the USD 68/bbl level to marginally extend on the prior day’s weakness which was triggered by reports that suggested Genscape forecast a 1.3mln build for Cushing stocks from 20th April. Elsewhere, gold languished as the greenback held onto the prior day’s advances, while copper also lacked demand alongside underperformance in Chinese riskier assets.

GEOPOLITICAL

North Korea Leader Kim met with South Korean President Moon in which the leaders shook hands and stepped on both sides of the border together holding hands, before they held talks. Following the talks, a South Korean presidential official said that North Korea leader Kim suggested to meet more often and is willing to visit South Korea's Presidential Palace, while Kim also said he attended the summit to put an end to history of conflict. (Newswires)

US

Most of the Treasuries action was concentrated in the belly and long end of the curve on Thursday with 10yr and 30yr yields falling by c.3bps, the former extending losses and pushing below 3% following the strong auction results. Thursday’s auction of 7-year debt was solid, stopping through the screens by 0.6bps, and the yield was the highest since April 2010. The bid-to-cover of 2.56x was also well above recent averages and the highest since January. Primary dealers were awarded the smallest share since the beginning of 2018, directs’ coverage was in close proximity to recent averages whilst indirects, a proxy for foreign demand, took the largest portion since January. US 10yr T-Notes futures settled 7+ ticks higher at 119-10.

ASIA-PAC MARKET WRAP: Asia traded mostly higher after Wall St. tech-led advances and historic inter-Korean summit
content: Asia equity markets traded mostly higher as the region got an uplift from the momentum in US where all majors extended on gains amid tech outperformance after strong Facebook results, which was later followed after-market by Amazon, Intel, Microsoft and Western Digital which all beat on earnings forecasts. As such, ASX 200 (+0.2%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.5%) traded positive although gains were relatively mild as participants also digested a flurry of data releases and earnings, while KOSPI (+0.6%) benefited from a warming of ties amid the historic inter-Korean summit. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-0.7%) and Hang Seng (+0.2%) were mixed with underperformance in the mainland following a neutral position by the PBoC in today’s open market operations, while data also showed a slowdown in the pace of Chinese Industrial Profit growth. Finally, 10yr JGBs were marginally higher with prices underpinned at the open to track the upside in USTs and with gains then held throughout the session including after an uneventful BoJ announcement in which it kept policy unchanged but removed the wording on reaching inflation goal around FY19.

Preview: BoJ expected to keep policy unchanged today
content:
The BoJ is scheduled to announce its latest policy decision later in which the consensus remains for no changes to QQE with Yield Curve Control and for NIRP to be maintained at -0.10%. The meeting will include the latest Outlook Report which contains bank officials’ forecasts for Real GDP and Core CPI, while it will also be the first meeting to be attended by newly appointed BoJ Deputy Governors Amamiya and Wakatabe.

The commentary from the BoJ continues to suggest no near-term policy changes being contemplated with Governor Kuroda recently reiterated that Japan needs strong accommodative monetary policy for some time, while he has also continuously repeated that the BoJ will maintain QQE w/ YCC for as long as necessary to reach the 2% target in a stable manner. In addition, the central bank has begun to mention the idea of normalization in which Kuroda stated the bank is internally discussing an exit from current monetary policy, although he added that they will not communicate it with the markets until policy normalizing timing draws near.

Elsewhere, the data suggests that policy tightening is unlikely to be anytime soon as CPI remains a far distance from the 2% price target with National CPI at 1.1% vs. Exp. 1.1% (Prev. 1.5%) and with Core CPI at 0.9% vs. Exp. 0.9% (Prev. 1.0%). Furthermore, the recent Tankan survey was somewhat inconclusive as large manufacturers’ sentiment deteriorated for the first time in 2 years and large industry indices and outlooks missed forecasts across the board, although the data also showed strong all industry capex expectations and increased confidence for smaller businesses.

As usual, there is no exact scheduled release time for the announcement which can be anytime from the start of the Tokyo lunch break at 0330BST/2130CDT/1030HKT. Alongside the decision and statement, the BoJ will release its latest projections which were affirmed across the board in January, and participants will be on the look-out if there are any changes to projections with the inclusion of the newly appointed Deputy Governors including known-reflationist Wakatabe.

Previous Outlook Report:
Real GDP
- Affirmed fiscal 2017 forecast at 1.9%.
- Affirmed fiscal 2018 forecast at 1.4%.
- Affirmed fiscal 2019 forecast at 0.7%

Core CPI
- Affirmed fiscal 2017 forecast at 0.8%.
- Affirmed fiscal 2018 forecast at 1.4%.
- Affirmed fiscal 2019 forecast at 1.8% (excluding effects of sales tax hike).
